lines.text: Enter ROSALIND and CELIA

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: Never talk to me I will weep.

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: Do, I prithee but yet have the grace to consider that tears do not become a man.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: But have I not cause to weep

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: As good cause as one would desire therefore weep.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: His very hair is of the dissembling colour.

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: Something browner than Judass marry, his kisses are Judass own children.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: I faith, his hair is of a good colour.

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: An excellent colour: your chestnut was ever the only colour.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: And his kissing is as full of sanctity as the touch of holy bread.

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: He hath bought a pair of cast lips of Diana: a nun of winters sisterhood kisses not more religiously the very ice of chastity is in them.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: But why did he swear he would come this morning, and comes not

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: Nay, certainly, there is no truth in him.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: Do you think so

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: Yes I think he is not a pickpurse nor a horsestealer, but for his verity in love, I do think him as concave as a covered goblet or a wormeaten nut.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: Not true in love

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: Yes, when he is in but I think he is not in.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: You have heard him swear downright he was.

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: Was is not is: besides, the oath of a lover is no stronger than the word of a tapster they are both the confirmer of false reckonings. He attends here in the forest on the duke your father.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: I met the duke yesterday and had much question with him: he asked me of what parentage I was I told him, of as good as he so he laughed and let me go. But what talk we of fathers, when there is such a man as Orlando

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: O, thats a brave man! he writes brave verses, speaks brave words, swears brave oaths and breaks them bravely, quite traverse, athwart the heart of his lover as a puisny tilter, that spurs his horse but on one side, breaks his staff like a noble goose: but alls brave that youth mounts and folly guides. Who comes here
Enter CORIN

lines.speaker: corin
lines.text: Mistress and master, you have oft inquired After the shepherd that complaind of love, Who you saw sitting by me on the turf, Praising the proud disdainful shepherdess That was his mistress.

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: Well, and what of him

lines.speaker: corin
lines.text: If you will see a pageant truly playd, Between the pale complexion of true love And the red glow of scorn and proud disdain, Go hence a little and I shall conduct you, If you will mark it.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: O, come, let us remove: The sight of lovers feedeth those in love. Bring us to this sight, and you shall say Ill prove a busy actor in their play.
Exeunt
